c74object.name: voicedrive~
c74object.description: voicedrive~ is a (sub)sample-accurate (usually non-interrupting) ramp generator with several useful outputs for driving grains, playback voices or other similar processes. Typically voicedrive~ is used in connection with the voicemanager~ object, as the drive unit for each individual voice of a process. Because voicedrive~ is a non-interrupting (in default mode) it can also be used for other sample-accurate timing purposes such as random length ramping (for interpolation between values for example).

objarg.name: hi-res
objarg.description: hi-res position mode flag (if on outputs position in hi-res for use with jkc's hr objects or similar).

objarg.name: allow-interrupt
objarg.description: Allow interrupts flag (normally you cannot interrupt a ramp / grain that is executing. If this flag is on triggers always start a new ramp).

method.name: First-inlet
method.description:
The first inlet takes a trigger signal used to begin the ramp outputs.
When not in mode 2, consecutive triggers will be ignored until the busy flag is lowered.

method.name: Second-inlet
method.description:
The second inlet takes a signal to determine the length (in milliseconds) of the ramp outputs.
This will effect the duration of the ramps, as well as the values of the ramp coming from the first outlet.
The input value is sampled when a trigger is recieved in the first inlet.

method.name: Third-inlet
method.description:
The subsample offset is for many applications not necessary. However, if for some reason you need better than sample-accurate timing (for pitched prcoesses et.) you can utilise this functionality.
It works by pre-advancing the ramps by the given subsample offset (between 0 and 1). The logic behind this is that for detection process, detection can only happen after the event (in this case crossing the 0 or 1 point) has taken place. Thus, the trigger occurs late by a fraction of a sample. To compensate for this, we advance the ramps by that amount to acheive subsample accuracy. Offset is applied to both the normalised and position ramps of voicedrive~ and voicemanager~ also takes account of the subsample offset.

method.name: Fourth-inlet
method.description:
The fourth inlet takes a signal to determine the offset (start value) in milliseconds of the ramp being output from the first outlet.
The input value is sampled when a trigger is recieved in the first inlet.

entry.name: signal
entry.description:
The first outlet outputs a linear ramp signal to indicate a playback position in milliseconds.
The second outlet outputs a normalised ramp signal (0-1).
The third outlet outputs a signal trigger at the beginning of each ramp.
The fourth outlet outputs the busy flag.
